example.text:
[PHARMACIST]: Hi Dr. Lee, I wanted to speak with you about Mr. James Carter, who’s being discharged today. He’s being started on warfarin for atrial fibrillation post-op, and I’m organising his discharge medications and follow-up.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s the current plan?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s had two doses of warfarin so far—5 mg on Day 1 and 3 mg yesterday. His INR this morning was 1.6, so still subtherapeutic. I’ve charted 3 mg again today, and we’ll need to arrange ongoing INR monitoring through his GP or local pathology service.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. Has the GP been contacted?
[PHARMACIST]: Not yet. I was going to ask if you’d like to send a discharge summary with a note to the GP to monitor INR every 2–3 days initially, and adjust dosing as needed. I’ll also include a warfarin education leaflet and a yellow book for tracking.
[DOCTOR]: Yes, please include that in the discharge paperwork. Has he been counselled?
[PHARMACIST]: Yes, I’ve spoken with him about, Dietary interactions (especially vitamin K), Bleeding risks, Signs to report (e.g. bruising, blood in urine/stool), Avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol, He’s aware and has agreed to follow up with his GP.
[DOCTOR]: Great. Any other meds to note?
[PHARMACIST]: He’s also on, Metoprolol 25 mg BD, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Paracetamol PRN, No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Perfect. I’ll finalise the discharge summary and include the INR plan. Thanks for organising everything.
[PHARMACIST]: No problem. I’ll send the warfarin pack with him and notify the GP clinic once he’s discharged.

[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Daniel Hayes, 67 years old, just returned from the cath lab following a coronary angiogram. He’s being transferred back to CCU for ongoing monitoring.
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. How did the procedure go?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Procedure was uneventful. No stents placed today—angiogram was diagnostic only. He still has the femoral sheath in situ, and it needs to be transduced for haemodynamic monitoring. His heart rate is low, sitting around 48 bpm, so we’re keeping a close eye on it.
[CCU_NURSE]: Okay. What are his current vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: BP: 110/68, HR: 48 bpm, sinus bradycardia, RR: 16, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 36.6°C, He’s alert and orientated, but a bit tired post-procedure.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any lines or medications?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes, a Femoral sheath – still in place, not yet transduced, IV cannula in left forearm, No IV infusions running currently, no sedation required post-procedure and probably has some usual meds
[CCU_NURSE]: Any pain or bleeding?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: No active bleeding. Puncture site is clean and dressed. No complaints of pain. He’s on bed rest, and we’ve reinforced strict leg immobilisation.
[CCU_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[CCU_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get the sheath transduced and continue monitoring his HR closely.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. All documentation is up to date.

example.text:
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, just returned from theatre after a urethral dilation and bladder washout. He’s stable post-procedure and ready for transfer to the ward.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. Can you give me a quick summary?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Sure. He was admitted with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. He had some clinical deterioration pre-op—low BP, reduced urine output, and confusion—but he’s responded well to treatment. He’s now passing urine via IDC, and output is improving.
[WARD_NURSE]: Vitals?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: His BP: 112/70, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, SpO?: 97% on room air, Temp: 37.4°C, Urine output: 120 mL in the last hour
[WARD_NURSE]: Any lines or attachments?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Yes he has an IDC draining clear urine, an IV cannula in left forearm, No infusions running currently and Oxygen via nasal prongs earlier, now weaned off
[WARD_NURSE]:
Any medications charted?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: He’s on Paracetamol 1g QID, Gentamicin IV stat dose given in theatre, PRN oxycodone and IV fluids were running intra-op, now ceased
[WARD_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: No, he’s English-speaking, fully alert and orientated. He’s a bit tired but understands what’s happening.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]: Hi Mr. Nguyen, this is your ward nurse, she’ll be looking after you now. You’re doing well after your procedure.
[PATIENT]: Thanks. I feel a bit groggy but better than before. Am I going back to my room now?
[WARD_NURSE]: Yes, we’ll get you settled in shortly. I’ll keep checking your blood pressure and make sure everything’s comfortable. If you need anything, just press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[RECOVERY_NURSE]:He’s due for post-op obs in 30 minutes, and the IDC needs to be monitored closely. Urology team will review later today.
[WARD_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[DIETITIAN]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert King, 58 years old, currently Day 3 post-abdominal surgery. He’s receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) via a central line due to nil oral intake and delayed return of gut function.
[NURSE]: Thanks. What’s the current TPN plan?
[DIETITIAN]: He’s on a standard TPN formulation with electrolytes, glucose, amino acids, and lipids. It’s running over 24 hours via central line, and we’re monitoring daily bloods—including U&Es, LFTs, glucose, and triglycerides. His fluid balance and weight should be tracked daily.
[NURSE]: Any specific concerns?
[DIETITIAN]: Yes, he’s at risk of refeeding syndrome, so we’ve started thiamine supplementation and are watching his phosphate and magnesium levels closely. So far, electrolytes are stable.
[NURSE]: Is he tolerating the TPN well?
[DIETITIAN]: Yes, no signs of intolerance. No nausea or vomiting. He’s alert and understands the plan. We’ve discussed the importance of not disconnecting the line and keeping the TPN pump running continuously.
[NURSE]: (to patient) Hi Mr. King, I’ll be looking after you today. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but okay. I’m just hoping I can eat again soon.
[DIETITIAN]: We’re aiming to reassess gut function in the next 48 hours. Once bowel sounds return and surgical team clears it, we’ll start clear fluids, then build up gradually.
[NURSE]: I’ll monitor his obs, fluid balance, and bloods. Anything else?
[DIETITIAN]: Just make sure the TPN line stays dedicated—no meds or flushes through it. And please notify me if there are any signs of infection, line issues, or abnormal blood results.
[NURSE]: Will do. Thanks for the handover.

[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old admitted with a urinary tract infection, now deteriorating—likely urosepsis.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: Over the past few hours, she’s become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered escalation. She’s also more confused than her baseline—normally oriented but now disoriented to time and place.
[DOCTOR]: Can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion)
[DOCTOR]: Has she had any recent bloods or cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes. Bloods were taken this morning: WCC: 14.2, CRP: 98, Creatinine: 102 (baseline ~85) Urine sample: Sent, we are waiting results Lactate: Not yet done—would you like it ordered?
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No current vascular access. She had a cannula yesterday, but it was removed due to tissuing. I can insert a new one now.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her fluid balance?
[NURSE]: Input (last 24h): ~1200 mL (oral + IV), Output: ~600 mL urine, no vomiting or diarrhoea, Net balance: +600 mL, Urine output: Reduced over last 6 hours—only 100 mL
[DOCTOR]: Allergy status?
[NURSE]: Documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling previously.
[DOCTOR]: Current medications?
[NURSE]: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, No antibiotics yet—awaiting review due to allergy
[DOCTOR]: Okay. I’ll assess her now. Let’s insert a cannula, take a lactate, and start IV ceftriaxone and gentamicin. We’ll monitor closely and consider AMU transfer if she worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll insert the cannula, draw the lactate, and prep the antibiotics. I’ll also notify AMU if her Q-ADDS increases or confusion worsens.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Nguyen, I need you to review Ms. Lara Bennett in bed 5. She’s a 56-year-old patient with a known history of epilepsy. She had a tonic-clonic seizure about 20 minutes ago on the ward. It lasted approximately 90 seconds and she’s now post-ictal—drowsy but rousable.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Is she stable now?
[NURSE]:Yes, she’s breathing spontaneously and maintaining her airway. No signs of trauma or tongue injury. She’s currently on 4-hourly neuro obs. Her latest vitals are:BP: 138/84, HR: 92 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 98% on room air, GCS: 13,Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + seizure)
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a patent IV cannula in her left forearm. No IV fluids running currently—she’s tolerating oral intake. No signs of dehydration.
[DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a documented allergy to phenytoin—rash and dizziness previously.
[DOCTOR]: Is she catheterised?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has an indwelling catheter (IDC) in place for monitoring. Output has been normal—clear urine, ~300 mL over the last 4 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, FBC and electrolytes were taken this morning: Hb: 128, WCC: 7.4, Platelets: 240, Na: 136, K: 4.2, Creatinine: 76, No major abnormalities.
[DOCTOR]: Has the family been informed?

[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with no signs of infection. There’s mild erythema around the edges. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended continuing with Allevyn Gentle Border dressing.
[Incoming Nurse]: How often does it need changing?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Every 3 days unless soiled or lifting. The next dressing change is due on Friday. We’re documenting progress in the wound chart and taking weekly photos for review.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re repositioning her every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other relevant care?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes:  she has No IV access currently, her Oral intake is adequate, there’s No IDC, but she is continent of urine and bowels, Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required, Skin integrity checks are ongoing, no other areas of concern
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue the pressure care, monitor the wound, and follow the dressing schedule.

[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday following a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but has significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination, especially upper limb function.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Thanks. What’s his current level of function?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. He’s mobilising with assistance but struggling with feeding, grooming, and dressing tasks. He’s right-hand dominant, which is now affected. He would benefit from an OT assessment for functional support and adaptive equipment.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any positioning or pressure care?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to support his hemiplegic side and prevent pressure injury. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and repositioned every 2 hours.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any IV access or medications?
[NURSE]: He has a 20G IV cannula in his left forearm—patent, no fluids running.

[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: What about nutrition and hydration?
[NURSE]: He’s on a soft diet with thickened fluids Level 2 as per speech pathology.
Fluid balance chart shows: Input (last 24h): ~1600 mL, Output: ~1400 mL (urine), total balance: of 200 mL. He’s tolerating oral intake well with supervision.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Any bowel issues?
[NURSE]: He opened his bowels this morning—formed stool, no concerns. Charted daily bowel monitoring.
[OCCUPATIONAL THERAPIST]: Thanks. I’ll assess his ADLs and see what supports we can put in place.
[NURSE]: Thanks. Let me know if you need assistance during the assessment or if any equipment needs to be ordered.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago following a manic episode. She’s now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder and is being discharged today. I’d like to arrange home supports to help her transition safely.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. Can you tell me about her current situation?
[NURSE]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband is supportive but understandably overwhelmed. He’s asked for help managing the household while Emily stabilises. She’s currently well but still adjusting to the diagnosis.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What kind of supports do you think she’ll need?
[NURSE]: She’ll benefit from: Domestic assistance (light cleaning, laundry, meal prep), Childcare support during the day, especially for the younger children, Mental health outreach for medication adherence and mood monitoring, Education for the family around bipolar disorder and crisis planning. Possibly pet care support if her condition fluctuates
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: No current risks identified. She’s engaging well, has insight, and is compliant with treatment. Her husband is aware of early warning signs and has contact details for crisis support.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: What’s her medication plan?
[NURSE]:
She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg – not used in the last 48 hours, she’ll need regular lithium level monitoring and follow-up with the community mental health team.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks. I’ll organise a home support package and liaise with the mental health team and family services.
[NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything further from the ward team.

[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s her current status?
[NURSE 1]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.8°C, HR 88, BP 118/76, RR 18, SpO? 99% on room air. Pain is sitting at 6/10, managed with IV analgesia. She’s nil by mouth pending review.
[NURSE 2]: Any imaging done?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, she’s had an abdominal ultrasound — inconclusive. CT abdomen is booked for this afternoon. Bloods show mild leukocytosis, CRP elevated. Urine is clear, pregnancy test negative.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yep, 20G in the left antecubital fossa — patent. She’s had IV fluids and analgesia. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and coping well. Just anxious about the possibility of surgery.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Anything else I need to follow up?
[NURSE 1]: Just keep an eye on her pain and nausea. Surgical team should be around shortly. Let me know if anything changes.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Dorothy Lane in bed 5. She’s an 83-year-old patient admitted with a left neck of femur fracture following a fall at home. She’s post-op day 1 following internal fixation. She’s currently confused, intermittently orientated, and requires full assistance with care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—due to confusion, elevated respiratory rate, and low urine output. Latest observations: BP: 118/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, she’s Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, she has a chronic venous leg ulcer on her right lower leg. It’s being dressed with Iodosorb and a foam dressing, reviewed by wound care yesterday. No sacral or heel breakdown noted. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she continent?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No, she’s incontinent of urine and has an IDC in place—draining clear urine, ~400 mL over the last 6 hours. She’s also on a bowel chart—no bowel movement today, last opened bowels yesterday.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any vascular obs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs on the affected limb: Sensation: Intact, Movement: Limited due to pain, Cap refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present, Skin temp: Warm.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She has a 20G cannula in her right forearm, patent.
Medications include: IV Cefazolin 1g TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Endone 2.5–5 mg Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily, No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, monitor her Q-ADDS, and update wound and fluid charts.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Singh, I need to speak with you about Mr. Jason Cole in bed 7. He’s a 49-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). He’s now requesting to self-discharge against medical advice.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. What’s prompting the request?
[NURSE]: He’s frustrated and says he “feels fine” and wants to go home. He’s been arguing with staff and mentioned needing to “sort things out” with his partner. He’s also expressed discomfort with being in hospital and says he doesn’t want to stay another night.
[DOCTOR]: Any safety concerns?
[NURSE]: Yes. He’s still on aspirin and enoxaparin and has not yet had his cardiology review. He’s a daily smoker and disclosed regular cannabis use. He’s currently on 2 L oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? sitting around 93%. He’s intermittently short of breath and still reporting mild chest tightness.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 132/84, HR: 102 bpm, RR: 20, Temp: 36.8°C, SpO?: 93% on 2 L O? and Q-ADDS score: 6 (due to HR, SpO?, and chest symptoms)
[DOCTOR]: Has he been informed of the risks?
[NURSE]: I’ve explained the risks of leaving before cardiology clearance, including potential for arrhythmia or further cardiac events. He’s aware but says he’s “not staying.” I’ve started the Against Medical Advice documentation and flagged it with the nurse unit manager.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll speak with him directly and assess capacity. If he’s determined to leave, we’ll need to complete the discharge summary and safety netting advice.
[NURSE]:
Understood. I’ll keep monitoring and let you know if his condition changes.

pred_spans.label: BACKGROUND
pred_spans.quote: He’s a daily smoker and disclosed regular cannabis use.

pred_spans.label: ASSESSMENT
pred_spans.quote: He’s currently on 2 L oxygen via nasal prongs, with SpO? sitting around 93%. He’s intermittently short of breath and still reporting mild chest tightness.

pred_spans.label: RECOMMENDATION
pred_spans.quote: If he’s determined to leave, we’ll need to complete the discharge summary and safety netting advice.

[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current status of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: The wound is approximately 4 cm in length, deep but not penetrating any major organs. It was cleaned and sutured in ED. There’s mild swelling and bruising around the site, but no signs of active bleeding or infection. Dressing is intact and due for review this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any neurovascular concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Neurovascular obs are normal his Sensation and movement in lower limbs are intact, the Capillary refill less than 2 seconds, and there are No signs of vascular compromise.
[Incoming Nurse]: What medications is he on?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s currently on: IV Ceftriaxone 1g daily, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain he has No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other monitoring?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: a Fluid Balance Chart: Input ~1200 mL, Output ~900 mL (urine via voiding), he has a Q-ADDS score: Currently 3 (due to pain and elevated HR) His vitals are stable. 
[Incoming Nurse]: Any psychosocial concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s cooperative but anxious. Police have been notified due to the nature of the injury. No visitors currently. Social work referral has been made.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue wound care, monitor his IV therapy, and update his charts.

NURSE: Dr. Lee, Mr. Matthews arrested about 40 minutes ago. We initiated CPR immediately and followed the ALS protocol. He was in asystole throughout. Despite full resuscitation efforts, we were unable to regain a pulse. Time of death was recorded at 11:42 AM.
DOCTOR: Thanks for the update. Were the family contacted?
NURSE: Yes, his wife and daughter are here now. They’re in the quiet room. I’ve let them know there was a serious deterioration, but they don’t know he’s passed yet.
DOCTOR: Alright. Let’s speak with them together. I’ll lead the conversation, and you can support with any nursing or practical details.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Ms. Bennett. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Bennett. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Rachel Bennett.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Rachel Bennett in Bed 2, Room 9, aged 52, under Dr. Wallace, Oncology Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Rachel, I’m Priya, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’re going through a lot right now, and I’m here to support you. Is it okay if we talk for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, please. I’ve been struggling a bit.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I know chemotherapy can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You mentioned concerns about work and home—can you tell me a bit more about what’s been difficult?
[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so. I just don’t know where to start.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s okay—I'll walk you through it. You’re not alone in this, and we’ll make sure you have the support you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check back in shortly, Ms. Bennett, and coordinate with Priya and Dr. Wallace’s team. Please use the call bell if you need anything.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Davies. I’m Jack, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Mr. Davies. This is Emma the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Michael Davies.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. And your date of birth? [PATIENT]: First July 1985. [OUTGOING_NURSE]: And your URN on the armband is 231879, which is what I have on the chart. So, Mr. Davies is under Dr. Kumar from Infectious Diseases — who I think will be the consultant covering this week. Mr. Davies was admitted yesterday with what seems to be acute gastroenteritis, most likely secondary to rotavirus infection. He’s currently being barrier nursed in isolation. Full PPE is required before entering — though I think they were short on gowns earlier, so check the supply trolley just in case. He’s on contact precautions, given the transmission risk.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s had several episodes of diarrhoea overnight — not sure how many. Managed with oral rehydration and IV fluids. No vomiting that I’m aware of. Stool sample was sent and the initial report suggests rotavirus, but the full panel isn’t back yet.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating small sips of water and bits of dry toast this morning. No abdominal pain reported, though he mentioned feeling “a little off” earlier. Continence aids are in use, and environmental services were notified for enhanced cleaning last night, but I’m not completely sure if they’ve been through yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Davies, how are you feeling this morning? Any nausea or cramping?
[PATIENT]: A bit tired, but no pain. Just still needing the bathroom a lot.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay, thanks. He’s aware of the need to remain in isolation and has mostly been cooperative with infection control steps. No visitors allowed at this stage, though I think his partner’s been trying to contact the ward. Dr. Kumar should be reviewing later today — I’m not sure of the exact time yet.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. I’ll keep monitoring his fluids, stool frequency, and general symptoms, and check in again after the review. If there’s any issue with supplies or isolation process, I’ll raise it with infection control.
[PATIENT]: No problem.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mr. Davies. Please use your call bell if you need anything. I’ll be finishing up my shift shortly.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I’ll be back soon to recheck your obs and update your chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Wendell. This is Sam, the incoming nurse for day shift. We’ll do a quick bedside handover if that’s okay.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Wendell. I’ll just check your ID band while Jack talks us through things.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed 3, is Wendell Mario Fleming, who is 41 years old, under Dr. Smith.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He came in with liver failure for investigation, and has a background of type 2 diabetes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Are his blood sugars in range?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, He’s still for bloods, and for a liver biopsy. CT and MRI are to be arranged as part of the plan.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Do you think they will get done today? if they are not too busy.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Should do, He’s a bit jaundice and He has been vomiting during my shift; I gave him some antiemetics with good effect.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How are you feeling now, Wendell?
[PATIENT]: Better than before. The nausea settled after the medication you gave me.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He was seen by the team today. They started IV fluids, running at 100 mls per hour.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: When was the cannula put in? or Any issues with the cannula?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: It was put in yesterday, He’s very difficult to cannulate, but the current line is patent and secure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep a close eye on it.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His obs have all been stable, and he’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Wendell, if you feel nauseated again or dizzy when you’re up and about, please press the call bell.
[PATIENT]: Will do.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up the bloods, check with radiology regarding CT/MRI timing, continue IV fluids at 100 mls/hr, monitor for nausea, and keep observing his vitals.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Wendell, anything you want to add before I head off?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Jack. I’ll be back shortly, Wendell.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Christina. I’m the day nurse, Sam. I’ll just get handover from Taylor here at your bedside if that’s okay.
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Christina. Bed 5, Christina Davis, who is 29 years old, under Dr. Mills. She originally presented with vomiting and was diagnosed with pneumonia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s pregnant, and she mentioned she has a 3-year-old daughter. She’s been coughing, particularly after talking.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Right.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s on oral antibiotics. Observations have been stable throughout my shift, with a QADDs of zero.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues overnight? 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No, nothing else to note.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Christina, how are you feeling now? Okay to speak or would you prefer short questions?
[PATIENT]: Talking makes me cough more.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Understood. Any nausea at the moment?
[PATIENT]: No, just the cough.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Taylor, any pending tests or consults?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None pending at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: The plan for the morning is to continue oral antibiotics as charted, keep observations going, minimize long conversations to reduce cough triggers, and call us if you feel more short of breath or the cough worsens.
[PATIENT]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve documented the stable obs and that she’s tolerating care.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Christina, I’ll come back shortly with your medications and to recheck your observations. Is the call bell is within reach?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll review your chart now and be back shortly to check in again. Thanks for the handover.

[PATIENT]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning. This is David Adams in bed 8, he is under Dr. Wu.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi David, I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: David, could you confirm your name for us please, and date of birth?
[PATIENT]: David Adams. 16 January 1984
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, David. Any allergies recorded?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: None recorded on the chart.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: David is 34, admitted with a head injury. He’s been having headaches and is photophobic.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:  He’s on Endone and morphine for the pain, and is for a CT brain tomorrow, and depending on those results, they’re planning to do endoscopic brain surgery later this week.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay,  I’ll keep an eye on the schedule for CT.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for daily bloods but he is a difficult stab, you may need to get the phlebotomist to do them, he's on neuro obs QID as per orders.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Have the bloods been taken today?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s pretty much self-caring and we’ve not noted any other issues.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: David, we’ll keep the lights a bit dim for your comfort with the photophobia and keep working on your pain relief. If your headache worsens or anything changes, please buzz.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: So the plan is to continue Endone/morphine for pain as charted, QID neuro obs, daily bloods, CT brain tomorrow, and wait for the surgical plan based on results.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Anything you want to add, David?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all good.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to do your next set of obs.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Alex. I’m Priya, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Sam, the night nurse. Is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Sure, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Priya. This is Alexander Marek in Room 4, under Dr Gaylor. Alex, can you confirm your full name and date of birth for us?
[PATIENT]: Alexander Marek, 12-09-58.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, thank you. Any allergies to medications?
[PATIENT]: None that I know of.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Okay. So, Alex is 66 years old, admitted with acute on chronic renal failure. He’s on home haemodialysis normally.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of end-stage renal failure, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and depression. He also has atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We need his warfarin level today to guide dosing. ED drew bloods but missed the warfarin/INR, so that still needs to be taken and then please get the doctors to review the result.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll take the INR straight after handover and flag it with the team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His potassium this morning is 6.2, so very high. The doctors are aware and we’re waiting on their treatment orders. I’ve printed the hyperkalaemia protocol and left it just outside the notes if you need it.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, I see it there. I’ll follow up for orders.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for renal ultrasound and biopsy to be arranged by the renal team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's for daily weight and he’s 82 kilograms today.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His Lying and standing blood pressures are stable—no postural drop.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: AV fistula observations are good: there’s a bruit and thrill present.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Blood glucose levels QID; latest BGL is 5.6.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Alex, do you usually dialyze Monday, Wednesday, Friday mornings?
[PATIENT]: Yes, M-W-F in the mornings. I had dialysis yesterday.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I’ve called the dialysis unit to let them know he’s admitted and needs scheduling while he’s here.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great, I’ll coordinate with them for the next session.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Otherwise he’s stable at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Alex, anything you want to add or anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll draw your INR now, and chase the team for the hyperkalaemia orders, 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sounds good. Thanks, Priya.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll get started now, Alex.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Natalie. I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just going to get bedside handover from Alex, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: That’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Natalie. So, this is room 4, bed 5. Patient is Natalie Caricas, 79 years old, under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She came in with stomach pain and jaundice. She has a Past history  which includes diabetes and obesity. She’s reporting feeling tired, a bit dizzy, and low in mood.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her urine has been very dark; I’ve sent a urine MCS. She arrived on the ward about three hours ago. Admission obs and paperwork are done, and her observations have been stable since arrival.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. Any mobility concerns?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she needs assistance with walking. I’ve flagged that she should be referred to physio.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay so shes an assist with all mobilising and falls precautions in place.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: yes. Diet-wise she’s on a diabetic diet. We’re doing QID BGL monitoring, and she’s on oral hypoglycemics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: QID BGLs and oral hypos—no insulin charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No insulin charted at present.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Pain management?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted for Endone and morphine PRN for pain. She’s been uncomfortable, so please assess and medicate as needed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Will do.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She hasn’t been seen by the medical team yet; she’s here for further investigation. We’re awaiting the team review under Dr Ross.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Natalie, how are you feeling right now—any pain, dizziness, or nausea?
[PATIENT]: My belly still hurts, and I feel a bit light-headed. I’m also just… a bit down.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you for telling us. I’ll check your observations now, get you some pain relief if it’s due, and make sure you’re safe when you get up. We’ll also let the doctors know how you’re feeling when they come.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me: her obs are stable a urine MCS was sent, she's an assist with mobility, and is on adiabetic diet with QID BGLs, oral hypoglycemics, PRN Endone/morphine charted, awaiting team review and physio referral.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. Natalie, your call bell is within reach—please ring before you get out of bed and we’ll come and help.
[PATIENT]: Okay, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Alex. I’ll take it from here.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following pneumonia. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her left hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with mild erythema around the edges. No signs of infection. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended Allevyn Gentle Border dressing. It’s due for redressing tomorrow unless it becomes soiled or lifts.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s currently on a standard mattress, but we need to contact QuEST to arrange a pressure-relieving mattress as soon as possible.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other care needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes: She needs a full wash this morning, including peri-care. Repositioning every 2 hours is in place. No IV access currently. Oral intake is adequate. No IDC – continent of urine and bowels. Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required. Skin checks are ongoing, and no other areas of concern noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll do her wash, redress the wound if needed, and follow up with QuEST for the mattress.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Sharma, I’d like you to review Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday with a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but showing significant right-sided weakness and difficulty with coordination.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s his current status?
[NURSE]: He’s alert and orientated, GCS 15. Vitals are stable: BP: 142/86, HR: 78 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 2 for (BP + mobility). He’s mobilising with assistance but has poor upper limb function on the right. He’s struggling with feeding and grooming tasks. I think he’d benefit from an occupational therapy referral to assess for functional support and equipment.
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm—patent and flushed. No IV fluids running currently.
[DOCTOR]: What medications is he on?
[NURSE]; He’s currently prescribed: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Perindopril 4 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN for comfort. No known drug allergies.
[DOCTOR]: How is he positioned?
[NURSE]: We’re using 30-degree lateral tilt positioning to offload pressure areas and support his hemiplegic side. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. I’ll review him and put in the OT referral. Please continue neuro obs and let me know if his mobility or cognition changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll also update the allied health team and document the referral request.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lang in bed 11. He’s a 71-year-old patient admitted yesterday following a left-sided ischemic stroke. He’s currently stable but has significant right-sided weakness and requires full assistance with mobility and personal care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: His Q-ADDS score is 2—based on his BP and reduced mobility.
Latest obs are BP: 142/86, HR: 78 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 96% on room air, GCS: of 15
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No current pressure injuries, but he’s high risk due to immobility. He’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re doing 2-hourly repositioning. Skin checks are ongoing—no redness or breakdown noted.
[Incoming Nurse]: What about hygiene needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He requires full assistance with hygiene. He had a full wash this morning including peri-care. He’s continent of urine and bowels—opened bowels yesterday, formed stool. No IDC.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his left forearm—patent, no IV fluids running.
Medications: Aspirin 100 mg daily, Atorvastatin 40 mg nocte, Perindopril 4 mg daily, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, hygiene support, and monitor his Q-ADDS.

[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current wound management plan?
[NURSE 1]: The area is dressed with a hydrocolloid dressing, changed every 72 hours or as needed. No signs of infection — no redness or discharge. Tissue viability nurse has reviewed and documented the plan.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He reports mild discomfort during dressing changes but otherwise tolerating well. Analgesia charted PRN — he had paracetamol this morning.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 22G cannula in the left forearm. It’s patent, no signs of phlebitis. Due for review tomorrow — charted for removal if no longer needed.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the site during rounds. Any meds due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on oral antibiotics — started two days ago for a UTI, due to complete in three more days. No known drug allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and engaging well. Mobilising with assistance. Pressure area care chart is up to date.
[NURSE 2]: Great, I’ll keep an eye on the wound and IV site. Let me know if anything changes.

[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What’s her current status?
[ED NURSE]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.6°C, HR 84, BP 122/78, RR 18, SpO? 98% on room air. The affected leg is red, warm, and swollen from mid-calf to ankle. No signs of abscess or necrosis.
[WARD NURSE]: Okay. What’s the antibiotic plan?
[ED NURSE]: She’s on IV cefazolin, 1g every 8 hours. First dose was given in ED about an hour ago. Next dose is due at 10 PM. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE]: Got it. Any IV access?
[ED NURSE]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — site is clean, dry, and patent. Charted for daily review. She’s also had IV fluids earlier, but now tolerating oral intake.
[WARD NURSE]: Any pain management?
[ED NURSE]: She’s had paracetamol 1g orally — pain is currently 4/10. PRN analgesia is charted.
[WARD NURSE]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[ED NURSE]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and understands the treatment plan. Mobilising with assistance due to leg discomfort.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the IV site and meds when she arrives. Let me know if anything changes before transfer.

[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mrs. Margaret Ellis, 87 years old, from Rosewood Nursing Home. She had a fall earlier this morning—staff found her on the floor next to her bed. She’s hit her head, and there’s a small occipital hematoma. No loss of consciousness reported, but she’s been drowsy and confused since.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any known medical history?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, she has: Hypertension, Osteoarthritis, Early-stage dementia and a Profound hearing loss – she’s deaf and communicates via written notes and gestures. No hearing aids in place today.
[ED NURSE]: Any medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: She’s on amlodipine and paracetamol regularly. No known drug allergies.
[ED NURSE]: What’s her current condition?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]:
Vitals on arrival: BP: 102/64, HR: 88, RR: 18, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 97% on room air
She’s responsive but confused. No vomiting. GCS is 14.
[ED NURSE]: Any advanced care directives?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, nursing home staff provided documentation indicating a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) order. There’s also a note that family must be involved in any escalation decisions. Her daughter and son are on their way to the hospital now.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any IV access?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No IV inserted yet. She may need one for imaging or fluids depending on your assessment.
[ED NURSE]:  We’ll get her triaged and notify the medical team. I’ll also make sure we have written communication tools available for her.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. She’s currently calm but may need reassurance once she’s in the bay.

[NURSE AMY]: Good morning, Ms. Carter. I’m Amy, and I’ll be your nurse for today. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, Ms. Carter. This is the nurse taking over for the day. Could you please confirm your full name?
[PATIENT]: Jessica Carter.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Jessica Carter in Bed 5, Room 11, aged 35, under Dr. Nguyen, Orthopaedic Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Carter was admitted yesterday following a fall at home. She has a displaced fracture of the right humerus and is scheduled for ORIF surgery tomorrow morning. She’s currently in a sling and on regular analgesia. Pain score was 6/10 earlier, now 3/10 after medication.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Neurovascular obs are intact: her Capillary refill <2 seconds, Sensation present, her Movement limited due to pain but preserved, there is No swelling or discoloration noted
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a single mother of two young children and has expressed concern about managing at home post-op. A social worker referral has been made to explore home support and childcare options.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: Hi Jessica, I’m Priya from physio. I’ve reviewed your chart and will work with you post-op to help regain movement and strength in your arm. For now, just rest and keep the arm supported. After surgery, we’ll start gentle exercises and discuss strategies for managing daily tasks one-handed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’m worried about how I’ll manage with the kids.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: That’s understandable. We’ll work closely with the social worker and nursing team to make sure you have the right support in place.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Jessica, I’m Mark from social work. I understand you’re concerned about managing at home after surgery. Can you tell me a bit about your current support system?
[PATIENT]: It’s just me and the kids. My mum lives interstate and I don’t have anyone nearby.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks for sharing. I’ll look into short-term home care options and community support services. We can also explore childcare assistance while you recover. I’ll keep you updated and help with any paperwork.
[NURSE AMY]: I’ll continue monitoring your pain and neurovascular status, and coordinate with the surgical team. Let me know if you need anything, Jessica.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I really appreciate it.

[NIGHT_NURSE]: Morning. Handing over Mrs. Evelyn Taylor, 81 years old, in bed 7. Evelyn, this is Nurse Mia, who’ll be looking after you today.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, I’ll be your nurse this morning. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: I feel a bit strange. My right arm feels heavy, and I’m having trouble speaking clearly.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: That’s actually new. She was drowsy overnight, but I thought it was just fatigue. I didn’t notice any clear deficits during the night, but she’s now showing slurred speech and right-sided weakness. I’ve just done a quick neuro check—there’s a facial droop and reduced grip on the right.
[MORNING_NURSE]: That sounds like a possible stroke. Has the doctor been notified?
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Not yet—I picked it up just before handover. I was about to escalate. She’s on Q-ADDS, scoring 6 now—due to new neuro changes and slightly elevated BP (162/94). HR 84, RR 18, SpO? 97% on room air, Temp 36.6.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll call the medical registrar immediately and start hourly neuro obs.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) I’ve just been informed. Evelyn, I’m Dr. Singh. We’re concerned you may have had a stroke overnight, and we’re going to do some urgent tests, including a CT scan.
[PATIENT]: Oh… I didn’t realise. I just thought I was tired.
[DOCTOR]: You did the right thing by speaking up. We’ll take care of you.
[MORNING_NURSE]: I’ll stay with her and start the neuro obs now. Is she nil by mouth?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, keep her NPO until we assess her swallow. I’ll organise an urgent stroke team review.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: She’s on a fluid balance chart, and her oral intake was minimal overnight. No IV fluids running yet. She’s on regular antihypertensives and aspirin. No known allergies.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll update the family once we have a clearer picture.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, med chart, and fluid balance.

[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Evelyn Grant, 87 years old, being transferred to the transit lounge to await transport back to her nursing home. Evelyn, this is Nurse Tom, who’ll be looking after you until your transport arrives.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, lovely to meet you. We’ll make sure you’re comfortable while you wait.
[WARD NURSE]: Evelyn was admitted five days ago with aspiration pneumonia. She’s responded well to IV antibiotics and supportive care. She’s now afebrile, respiratory rate is 18, SpO? 96% on room air, and she’s mobilising short distances with assistance.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Great. Any swallowing concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, she has known dysphagia—thickened fluids and minced moist diet. She’s been reviewed by speech pathology and is safe to resume her usual nursing home diet plan. No signs of aspiration since admission.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Okay. Any medications due?
[WARD NURSE]: No meds due during transit. She’s had her morning meds—oral antibiotics completed yesterday. No allergies. She has a 22G IV in the left hand, but it can be removed before discharge.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Any behavioural concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: No. She’s pleasant, a bit confused at times but reorients easily. Nursing home staff are aware and familiar with her baseline.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Got it. Is transport booked?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, booked for 11:30 AM. All discharge paperwork is complete, including medication summary and nursing home handover form. Please let the team know if there’s any delay or change in her condition.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Frank. I’m the day nurse coming on now my name is Henry. I’ll get a quick handover from Arthur at the bedside if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi. This is bed 5, Frank Morgan Montgomery. Frank, this is the incoming nurse who’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Frank—could you tell me your full name and date of birth.
[PATIENT]: Frank Morgan Montgomery, 25 October 1947.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Frank is 78 years old and under Dr. Sanchez. He came in with shortness of breath and tiredness post‑op. He has a history of CABG eight years ago. We’ve noted a decreasing level of consciousness, so neuro observations are being done QID. He was tachy this morning—post‑op—and he’s on oxygen at 3 liters via nasal prongs. His oxygen saturations are all good now. He’s here for further monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Has there been any changes to his LOC since earlier?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's a little drowsy compared to baseline but rousable; no acute deterioration since last my last round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep a close eye and escalate if there’s any decline. Frank, how’s your breathing feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Better than before, just a bit tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. We’ll continue monitoring your heart rate, breathing, and level of alertness. If you feel more short of breath or more drowsy, please let us know.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding—bloods, scans, or new orders?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders noted; just ongoing monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll check your vitals shortly, Frank, and make sure you’re comfortable. Do you need anything before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, Frank. I’m heading off now. You’re in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back in a moment to recheck your observations.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dave, I’m Jess, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam who’s finishing the night shift. Is it okay if we talk through things at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yeah… okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Dave. So, this is Room 2, Bed 3: Dave McKenzie, 72 years old. He’s a new admission, arrived a few hours ago under Dr George De Silva with a background of dementia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dave, can you tell me your name?
[PATIENT]: Dave… McKenzie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, Dave. I’ll just check your ID band… all good.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Presenting issue is increasing confusion. They’re querying a UTI. He’s still for bloods and a urine MCS—I haven’t had a chance to do those yet. They’ve started him on oral antibiotics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so I need to do bloods and a urine MCS. I’ll get onto those this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His medical history includes CCF, hypertension, type 2 diabetes on oral hypoglycemics, and he has chronic back pain, in addition to the dementia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s resting in bed at the moment. I haven’t seen him mobilise yet, so I’d suggest a physio referral. He’s also been refusing his meals, so a dietitian referral would be helpful.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll place referrals to physio and dietetics and reassess his intake.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His observations have been stable since arrival. No other acute concerns noted.I have been watching him to make sure he doesn't go wandering off the ward.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. Hi Andreas, this is Priya, she’ll be looking after you today.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll check the charts.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cecilia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in Bed 1, This is Cecilia Ramos, 38, under Dr Willow. Admitted with a renal obstruction; Her full history is in the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band, Cecilia… great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She had a CT scan last week. She has been charted pain medication. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s still there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye on your timing and make sure you’re comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Plan is to discharge at the end of this week and Follow‑up with Dr Willow one week post discharge and book a renal outpatients appointment for two weeks after discharge. The discharge summary is at the front of the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are we just waiting on medications to go home?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes we are waiting for the discharge meds from pharmacy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  I’ll chase those up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s quite anxious. Family is in attendance at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, we’ll keep you updated about timing and the medications so you’re not left wondering.
[PATIENT]: I appreciate that. I’ve been a bit worried.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course. I’ll check in regularly, and if anything changes with your pain or you have questions, press the call bell.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. See you tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else you’d like us to know or anything you need right now, Cecilia?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up pharmacy and be back shortly.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Mary, I’m Alex, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do bedside handover?
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you tell me your full name and date of birth, please?
[PATIENT]: Mary Ocas 21st Feb 2005.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks, Mary. Any medication allergies?
[PATIENT]: No, none.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: I'll check your ID number 509127. ok Mary is 20 years old, under Dr Forbes. She came in with severe abdominal pain.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s charted regular paracetamol for pain and I think some other PRN meds. She’s also written up for metoclopramide as an anti-emetic. Bloods and observations were taken but not sure on progress
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s scheduled for a colonoscopy tomorrow, so I guess needs to be nil by mouth from midnight tonight for the procedure. Otherwise, she’s self-caring and ambulant.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mary, how is your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll check the timing of your next regular paracetamol. Any nausea?
[PATIENT]: A little earlier, but okay now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: If it returns, we’ve got some medications you can have for that — just use the call bell.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me I'm off to the shops.

[PATIENT]: Okay, thanks.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything you need before we go, Mary?
[PATIENT]: I’m fine, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—press the bell if you need anything. I’ll be back shortly.
